headline.main: 'SIN' LEVIES ONLY ADD TO ALCOHOL'S ALLURE

byline.original: By MORRIS E. CHAFETZ; Dr. Morris E. Chafetz, president of the Health Education Foundation, a group supported both by the public and the liquor industry, was founding Director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the current political climate, the push to control drinking behavior is getting out of control. This pursuit is manifesting itself now in the cry for increased taxes on alcoholic beverages. Apparently 4,000 years of repressive laws have taught our social engineers nothing. They still believe that drinking behavior can be controlled through legislation. From the time of the Whiskey Rebellion about 200 years ago, alcohol taxes have been billed as a way to raise revenues while accomplishing a worthy social goal. This long history helps make legislators' tasks easier and salves consumers' guilty consciences. Consequently, the levy of taxes on alcohol implicitly represents what is known as ''a safe harbor,'' allowing legislators the freedom to exploit consumer willingness to pay ''sin'' taxes.
